subject: Basketball
Amateur Athletics
College Athletics
lead_paragraph: Billy Donovan, who coached the Florida men’s team to its second consecutive N.C.A.A. title last month, and Pat Summitt, who coached the Tennessee women to their seventh title in her 33 years on the job, received the annual Winged Foot Awards last night at a dinner at the New York Athletic Club. The award is given annually to the coaches of the men’s and women’s N.C.A.A. basketball champions, and Summitt may return next season. She lost only two seniors, and she kept the 6-foot-4 Candace Parker, probably the best player in the women’s game. The Volunteers also have one of the strongest recruiting classes in the nation with Angie Bjorklund, a 6-1 guard-forward from Spokane, Wash.; Kelley Cain, a 6-6 center from Atlanta; Vicki Baugh, a 6-4 forward-center from Sacramento; and Sydney Smallbone, a 6-0 guard from South Bend, Ind. “We have a chance to be a very good team next year,” Summitt said at a news conference. Donovan, however, said: “We’re very young. We’re starting over. We lose our top six players.” Four of those six were underclassmen who have declared for the N.B.A. draft.
